This handle allows you to launch and land the Mavic from your hand. I designed this because I will often be launching and catching it off of a moving boat. Before you mount it to your Mavic, make sure you turn off the downward sensors. This handle quickly mounts to the two rubber legs on the back. It flies fine and I have taken it out in heavy wind.

I printed at 90% solid because I didn't want to risk breakage and It seems plenty sturdy.

Disclaimer: In the event of an immediate emergency landing (which I've never experienced in 4 years of flying) it appears that the gimbal would be mostly protected by the arms, but it will definitely break propellors with the handle installed.

XYZ Davinci AIO

Yes

90%

comments.text: Thanks for the question. You're actually incorrect. If it had to land itself, it would fall forwards and just break the two front propellors which are relatively cheap. Check out the Mavic torture videos on youtube. it can take much more abuse than a bad landing! Also, I have been flying DJI products since the phantom 1 and I have never had any sort of emergency landing. I have flown in temperatures from -30 degrees to 110 degrees and even in rain and snow with no issues. The worst I have experienced is Return To Home in which case you can just catch it.

comments.text: Does it shoot up? Or slightly increase altitude? If you still have complete control, you may be experiencing what happens without the downward sensors. description.text:
The ZYYX 3D Printer comes equipped with an exhaust fan and an active carbon filter. For working with benign materials like PLA, especially in a large room, this is probably sufficient. However, I anticipate working with other less benign materials in the near future. This exhaust duct system was designed to port the exhaust outdoors as my printer is in my home office.

For this installation, I needed only a 2 foot length of aluminum ducting because the window is close to the printer. It is Deflecto Aluminum Duct with Connectors, Semi-Rigid, Flexible, 4” x 2ʼ. On Amazon, it costs about $5 as an Add-on item. The duct is a snug fit on both ends but tape (such as electricianʼs tape) makes up for out-of-roundness in the aluminum duct. A window filler had to be custom-made to fit my sliding glass window. Holes were cut in it for the exhaust port and for the four screws.

The black four-inch-flange has a bolt-pattern that matches the exhaust fan assembly on the ZYYX. The original four screws holding the fan in place were removed and replaced with longer screws to accommodate the flange.

title: NRG Energy San Diego Side Panels Mug

description.text:
*The first time I printed this file, there was a hole in the side due to a glitch in the STL file with the splines. I fixed it, and, although it looks weird, this STL prints perfectly.

Well. This was quite a design to modify. I have participated in every challenge since I joined Thingiverse, and I didn't want this one to be any different. I chose to modify the NRG Energy (San Diego) Server Cabinet Blanking Panels for two reasons. Firstly, this design is really detailed and impressive. I didn't actually know what NRG Energy was when I first looked at this design, so I visited NRG's twitter page, which confirmed that they are a great company whose philosophy-as well as architecture- should be preserved on Thingiverse forever.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

1mm (High)

Infill:

10-15%

Notes:

This print took me 11 hours, and I did it at 50% scale. In other words, it is probably best to print it overnight.

Safety announcements

Even though I called this a mug, I WOULD VERY STRONGLY ADVISE AGAINST DRINKING HOT LIQUIDS OUT OF IT.
Although PLA is safe to drink out of, it will soften and release plastics into your hot beverage.

If you somehow beg SpaceX or someone to print it out of a metal, I am very jealous. Please send me a pic and feel free to drink whatever you want out of it.

Design Process

Initially, this design started out as Marciot's design. I was really impressed by the detail and complexities he managed to fit onto his NRG Design. Marciot then modified it and remixed it into various panels.

When making this design into a mug, I faced several issues. Mainly, there is no good way to draw on the side of a circle in CAD. To create the circular face of a mug, I created a 50-sided polygon (basically a circle, but with sides that CAD allows you to easily create sketches on). I wrapped the first panel from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:943239 around the sides of the polygon, and came up with half a mug. I didn't want half a mug. I wanted a full mug. So I mirrored the design, and ended up with a full mug. All I had to do was add the handle and print it.

Please. Add. Onshape.

I'm sorry to complain, but I really really REALLY wish that Thingiverse would add OnShape under the design tools used button. OnShape is awesome, and allows me to do almost everything I could do in Autodesk Inventor online.

title: Prusa i3 Mk2 Z Threaded Rod Center Cap

description.text: Use this to center the Z Threaded rod on your Prusa i3 Mk2 if it is out of center or wobbling in place.

comments.text: This is not a good idea. The holes where the z axis threaded rods go through are over sized for a reason. A rod that is not perfectly straight, as many are not, needs to be free to wobble otherwise the bearing on the smooth rod will bind as the threaded rod will apply undesirable force to the bearing. A bit of threaded rod wobble does not matter as it is the smooth rods and bearings that stabilise the Z axis.
comments.author: Geoffs

comments.text: How does that theory check out with perfect rods?
comments.author: Geoffs

comments.text: The hole in the top bracket is larger than the threaded rod diameter for a good reason, this is a deliberate design decision. Many threaded rods are not perfectly straight. The top end of the rod is left free to wobble so any small bend in the rod has no effect on the X or Z axis accuracy. Putting a cap on a bent rod will stop the wobble at the top, but the rod is still bent. This causes the wobble to show up further down the rod so the motor and smooth rod bearing will struggle to try and straighten the threaded rod.a slightly bent rod is not an issue if the top end is leftfree to move,  however a badly bent rod  (ie the wobble at the top is too great to be accommodated by the hole in the top bracket) should be replaced. Putting caps on perfectly straight rods is probably ok but why bother? But capping a slightly bent rod defeats the deliberate design decision and will cause problems with increased friction, binding and stress on the coupler.
comments.author: gustofusion

comments.text: I liked this idea but instead of printing a part, I wrapped the top 5mm of the threaded rod in heat-shrink tubing so that it doesn't clatter against the side of the 3D-printed Z-support parts. The Z-rods are still free to wobble so no potential binding issues, but noise is reduced.

A 3D printable Twilicane! (or Twilight Sparkle'Âs sceptre). This appeared for about 3 seconds in a recent episode of My Little Pony Friendship is Magic and somehow became a massive meme overnight, so I decided what the world really needs is a real one and here it is. Enjoy!

You will need:- -One 400mm long 22mm diameter wooden dowel (I got a meter of it from eBay for about Â£2.50) -One can of Gold spray paint (again I got it from eBay. a 250ml can which was only just enough for Â£3.85) -One 40mm diamond cut Equestrian ruby, cut from the earth by Diamond Dog gem masters and imbued with the magic of Celestia herself... or, if you don'Ât have access to one of those you could do what I did and buy a cut glass paperweight from eBay just search for 'Âdiamond cut red glass gem'Â and look for one about 40mm across. the one I got was Â£4.24. There are two parts to print, the head and the gem holder, the gem holder is an easy and quick print and needs no support but the head is slightly more difficult and does need support. The rod should just press fit into the head so no fixings should be needed there but the gem holder needs gluing to the end and the gem needs gluing into the gem holder. Just use a hot glue gun for this. Depending on the tolerance of your printer and the rod you get you may need to sand the ends of the rod to get it to fit. The rod I was sent ended up as 22.4mm instead of 22mm. The parts should be sprayed separately before assembly to get a good covering. Both parts were printed on a Replicator MK1 in ABS with a layer height of 0.15 a 20% infill and no shells. The head took about 8 hours and the gem holder half an hour. To finish off the parts acetone vapour was used (parts placed in a glass container with acetone at the bottom placed on the heated printer bed) it seems to work best if both parts are treated after being sprayed as the paint will also smooth out in acetone vapour.

description.text:
This is a model of Odyssey, the command-service module for Apollo 13.
July 5, 2017: I have completely remodeled and improved Odyssey. I fixed the large hole for a window, and I enlarged the thrusters.

Printer:

HICTOP Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

High

Infill:

10% or more

Notes:

You must print this with supports, and the linear thrusters will fall apart if you print it on fast. I recommend printing it on high resolution. If you are planning to display it, print it from the bottom up so you get a better finish on the top, where everyone can see it. I printed with PLA filament, but you can use any material.
NOTE: Thrusters may or may not fall off. Some do, some don't. When I printed the new version I added on July 5, 2017, I only lost 2 out of 8 total thrusters. In the earlier version, I lost the vast majority.

Tip:

I used more than one CAD software: one for the main design and one for the details.

title: Mosfet & mainboard support frame for Anet A8
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
UPDATE:I uploaded a small, mini and micro version, basically, the only thing that matters is the bridge between the mainboard mount and the mosfet. If you use 4 the white washers that are originally used to mount the mainboard, on the upper side of the mainboard and the lower side of the mosfet, you're good to go. Faster print, less wasted plastic.

Needed a frame for my mosfet board on my Anet A8. I thought The original design (1857006) was a bit wasteful, both in print time and plastic, since the design aspect would be completely covered by the actual boards anyway. Hence this design, which saves +/- 50% of time and plastic. I actually designed this from the ground up with Adobe Illustrator and Blender, but i did use Sjouke's file for measurements.

How to connect the mosfet board: https://3dprint.wiki/reprap/electronics/heatbed_mosfet

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Notes:

I used 100% infill, 0.2mm layer height, printed with a brim.
According to Cura, this should be about 13-14 grams (with 100% infill), less than 5 meters filament, and take about 1h10m.

comments.text: Nice job.  This one works well.  I left the nuts out of the bottom two MOSFET holes and instead drilled two new holes in the printer frame to keep it securely attached.

description.text:

These will only work if you have the same type of cube walls as we do, and I have no idea whatsoever how to know anything like make or model of the cube walls, so they probably won't be terribly useful to many people, but here they are.

title: Z Axis Optical Endstop for Geeetech Prusa I3 Pro

description.text:
Update 1/28/18 I added a retainer to secure the stop flag in its holder. I relied on a friction fit on an earlier version and when I replaced it, I found there wasn't anything to secure the flag. You can mount it either way in the holder, depending upon whether you are using a printed flag or a thinner one made out of plastic or card-stock.

UPDATE 1/30/17 The holes in the printer frame and/or the holes in the bracket that mounts to the printer frame are over-size for the 2.5 mm screws that Geeetech originally furnished for the micro switch. Also, the holes on the frame of my printer appear not to be parallel to the horizontal line of the printer frame. There isn't any problem with the frame bracket being out of square with the frame as far as the flag actuating the optical module, but the over-size holes allow the optical module to be moved up and down if the bracket holding the optical module is bumped inadvertently. This can move the end point and allow the extruder to end up too high or low when homed. I've found it is best to push the bracket to its lowest position and then make sure the screws are tight. Another potential fix is to switch to 3 mm screws and/or place some contact cement on the bracket before mounting it to the frame and make sure it is in the lowest position when fixed in place.
UPDATE 12/29: I've been using this for almost a month now, and am very pleased with the way it works. It seems very repeatable. Between this and the nut keepers on the printer bed, my printer bed holds adjustment much better than it used to when I got it a year ago.

After having two micro switches fail in less than a year of use, the option of using an optical sensor end stop switch seemed like a worthwhile thing to try. Switches that do not provide a consistent switch point can be tolerated in the X and Y axis, but precision is a necessity in the Z axis if your bed control is manual.

The two printed assemblies here, plus a purchased optical module provide an optical endstop that replaces the microswitch on the Z axis of Geeetech I3 Pro printers. It can probably be adapted to other printers that use the same metal brackets as the Pro series on the X carriage.

First, my thanks to Ablapo for his design, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:27544, which provided the inspiration. I wish I could have used it as-designed in my printer.

Besides the printed parts, The following parts are needed:
1 Ramps 1.4 Optical Endstop and cable, eBay, Aliexpress or other.

1 square post for connecting 5V power to endstop cable (or solder to board (recommended))

Misc soldering tools and shrink tube.

2 #4 x 1/2 inch SAE sheet metal screws or similar size metric sheet metal or machine screws for mounting optical switch to the printed bracket..

1 3MM cap screw as furnished by Geeetech for Z-Endstop adjustment (to provide adjustment of optical sensor).

1 Spring, as furnished for Z-End stop by Geeetech;

1 6d Finishing Nail or similar smooth steel rod approximately 0.092 in. diameter to stabilize the position of the optical sensor.

2 short #4 sheet metal screws or machine screws to hold the stop flag coarse adjustment in the movable carriage. These are not needed if the flag is glued or friction-fitted into the flag holder.

Steel washers, 3mm 3 for the spring and cap screw. a couple more if you use screws to hold the flag into the bracket.

The assembly that is mounted on the X axis carriage holds the stop flag which enters the gate in the optical switch when nearing the stop point. This assembly allows a coarse height adjustment of the stop flag. It can accommodate a wide range of extruders by raising or lowering the stop flag fixed position. This allows the fine adjustment on the fixed assembly to have a limited adjustment range without the spring being too tight or too loose.

The assembly mounted on the frame attaches to the mounting holes that were used for the microswitch. It provides fine Z-adjustment of the optical sensor using a 3mm machine screw. A smooth steel rod on the sensor holder moves in a clearance hole and keeps the sensor in alignment.

The optical sensor is powered by 5vdc which can be tapped from the main controller board or the display panel. The other two wires of the optical sensor connect to the existing wires that connected to the micro switch. These two wires provide a 5v ground and the output signal used by the processor board. Use a voltmeter connected to 12v low to determine which is the signal and mark it for connection to the optical module.

I added a knob for adjustment, but the screw furnished with the printer may not be long enough to use it without compressing the spring more than desirable. If you want to use a knob, use a longer screw with a nut run up tightly against the head and insert it in the bottom of the fixed frame piece. Put the knob on the top of the movable piece, where the adjustment cap screw head is in the pictures. It looks like there will have to be a spacer under the knob to clear the sensor. You can use the washers included; they can be scaled up in size ant thickness to do the job.

It's worth mentioning that the photos show development parts and in most cases are not the same as submitted here; I never updated the parts on my printer. If I screwed up, and the changes don't work, please let me know, so I can fix it.

The LED on the sensor lights when the flag is not blocking the path. In practice, the LED never extinguishes. When the flag triggers it momentarily, the end point is sensed and the stepper motors stop. In my case, the LED remains lighted after the motors stop, however it is not at full brightness, which indicates there is a lot of noise in the module. A capacitor across the module might be helpful, but the switch point seems very repeatable as noted by the stopped position of the stepper motors. If anyone tries to correct this situation, let me know so I can add your findings. This printer is an EMI nightmare; it drives my digital caliper crazy if it is within several feet of it.

UPDATE 12-2-16
I added knob2. This offers another way of adding a knob to the adjusting screw. It is attached to the head of the cap screw by heating the screw with a soldering iron and pressing it into the knob. If it comes off when it cools, a drop of CA glue might be enough to keep it in place more or less permanently. The best way to get it on straight is to drop the hot screw into a clearance hole in a piece of wood or other material and then press the knob firmly in place over the head. It can be reheated (at the base of the head) and repeated as necessary. The hole in the front of the printer base for the Y carriage belt adjustment is a good hole to use. Put a washer on the screw to make sure the screw is fully supported when you press against it.
UPDATE 12-3-16
I shortened the vertical blade on the X carriage base to get it out of the way of the knob and added it as Base 2.... The change shouldn't interfere with use on the target printer.

Notes:
The pitch of a 3mm adjustment screw is 0.5 mm or 0.020 in. A quarter turn of the knob or screw moves the Z set point 0.125 mm or 0.005 in.

The downside of using a square pin connector on the power to the optical module is that if the power connector happens to get knocked off, the carriage will crash into the bed when homed.

I'm not using the latest parts, but when I see something that can be improved, I make a change. The downside is that I may upset something that I don't see. The only way I'll know is if I get feedback. If you run into something that doesn't fit or work well, please let me know and I'll try to fix it.

12/6 added photo of Knob2 pressed onto the original z-adjust screw.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

I used 0.2LH and a 0.4 mm nozzle

Infill:

about 20% 3 top/bottom layers

Notes:

I printed the pieces using two perimeters. The holes are sized so that minimum material has to be removed if using the parts I used. If you use different sizes, then it may be good idea to use more perimeters if you anticipate opening the holes significantly. I use a drill bit turned manually to open the hole for the smooth rod so it is loose and does not bind when the carriage moves during adjustment of the end point. The holes that the 3mm adjustment screw runs in should be a tight fit.

For the carriage mounted assembly, the bracket that holds the flag and the fixed bracket will probably need to be filed so the flag holder hangs over the fixed bracket squarely.

When it comes to assembly, it is important to use steel washers on each side of the spring, and even more important to polish the ends of the spring so they don't bind against the washers and cause backlash (as they did in the original configuration). Almost any stone will work to polish off the sharp edge at the ends of the spring.

The head of the nail must be cut off. There are crimp marks where the wire was held when the head was formed. I cut the head off at the 4th crimp mark from the top. The bottom of the nail must be cut off to yield a length of close to 25 mm. If it is too long, it will hit the frame of the printer and limit the movement of the sensorThe nail must be pressed into the sensor holder. It should fit very tightly. Use CA to glue it if there is any doubt. It should be parallel and in the same plane as the 3mm screw.

The screws that hold the sensor to the bracket have to be tapped into the sensor holder. Use a soldering iron to GENTLY heat the screw head and thread it into the plastic, reheating briefly when it becomes difficult to turn.

The nut cavity in the lower fixed bracket will probably have to be cleaned out if infill falls into it. The nut can be heated gently and pressed into the cavity, making sure that the screw will thread into it without damaging the screw bore.

For the assembly that mounts on the frame in place of the micro switch, there are two holes that will have to be finished with a drill bit or file. The hole for the 3mm screw can be sized by threading in the screw and turning it to ream the hole. It should be a reasonably tight fit.

The hole for the smooth rod should be comfortably loose and smooth so the rod can slide in it without catching. Its only function is to keep the sensor holder from rotating.

If you use a printed flag, the bottom few mm must be painted as PLA or ABS is not opaque to the switch. You can use credit card material or cardboard and fit it tightly into the holder, then glue it when you are in the right range.

title: GameBoy Pocket and Game Mounting Brackets

description.text:
These are brackets designed to hold Gameboy Pockets and games in a shadowbox. They have been designed so that the items can be easily removed at any time. The holes have been designed to accommodate M3 sized screws.

gameboy game mount2.stl --This is the original design that has a clip on the top. This proved more difficult to quickly remove the game but holds the game in place a little stronger.
gameboy game mount 2 redesign.stl --This is the game redesign where the top clip has been removed and the bottom mounts have been extended. Games are easier to remove with this design.
gameboy pocket mount 3.stl --Gameboy pocket mounting bracket. This isn't the best design in the world but it works. Print with supports.

More pictures can be found here: http://imgur.com/a/qgmDf

print_settings.Notes:: I print the one-sided version flat and the two-sided on end with manually added tree-like supports to steady it.  I figure that the ring and keys will rough up the end with the hole, so I put that end down when printing the two-sided version because then any support marks won't matter. An infill of 100% is recommended if the filament is not completely opaque.

description.text:
An old school hotel/motel key fob modeled after the ones used by chain and independent motels across the US in the 50's, 60's, 70's, etc. These fobs were often stamped with the room number, motel logo & address, and a message that postage would be paid if dropped in any US mail box.

STL files for one and two sided versions are available as well as the OpenSCAD code used to create them. Fob dimensions are parameterized in the code, so the fob could be customized (though I did not design it for the customizer and have not added any parameter validation code).

Printer:

FlashForge Finder

Infill:

25 to 100%

Notes:

I print the one-sided version flat and the two-sided on end with manually added tree-like supports to steady it. I figure that the ring and keys will rough up the end with the hole, so I put that end down when printing the two-sided version because then any support marks won't matter. An infill of 100% is recommended if the filament is not completely opaque.

title: Wallete - Simple Wallet
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I would love to keep sharing my projects with all of you. If you enjoy with my designs, I invite you to become a patron, you will get early access to my designs and exclusive content! Also, you can help with a small donation. Patreon: http://www.patreon.com/flowalistik
Donations: http://www.paypal.me/flowalistik

Hi, I'm here to present you my latest creation. Because of my lifestyle I needed a solid and functional wallet, and as I dind't find it in any store, I designed it. I called it Wallete because I took the shape and simplicity from a cigarette pack. Also I created some logo and brand, but it doesn't matter. *the pictures were taken with a normal size Wallette (the biggest version). **Despite the 3ds models are displayed horizontally, the should be printed vertically. Wallete description:

  • It only has 2 parts (body and cap).

  • simple design, with no hinges or strange things.

  • Designed to be printed without support material.

  • It can be customized a lot. Paint, texture, patterns, etc. the 3d model is easily customizable.
    • I've designed 3 DIFFERENT VERSIONS:

  • Normal: inside 22mm. It can hold 20 cards. I designed it with a separation part in the middle so you can maintain togheter 10 cards and carry random stuff in the other half.

  • Mini: inside 17mm. It can hold 15 cards. It still has separation.

  • Slim: inside 12 mm. It can hold 10 card. It has no separation.
    • Hope you like it! Edits: 14/12/13 Fixed the mistake in the design of the cap in the Mini Version.

author: LBDub

title: Ship hold containment structure for cylindrical containers

description.text:
Containment structure for cylindrical (sub)containers in a ship's hold. This is part of a rather sizeable project that, at the time of uploading this, is still a long way away from being complete.

I originally started modelling the ship whose hold this goes into as a toy coin carrying vessel and/or novelty coin collection storage box for coin collectors.

This structure goes into one of 3 main compartments in the ship's hull.

half1.zip and half2.zip are each high resolution .stl mesh exports of one half of the model.

The other .zip files are various 3D file format, lower granularity exports of the entire model.

The images are 3D renderings of the lower granularity exports of the entire model generated using POVRay.

Please note that this model was intended for being printable using highly accurate, powder bed SLS or SLM 3D printers. As such the model may not be suitable for easy or accurate rendition on a FLM or FFF 3D printer.

Hopefully you can make due and manage to print on whatever printer you own. I have no 3D printing experience (I only have 3D modelling experience) and no 3D printer of my own nor have I had this model printed using a 3D printing service so, unfortunately, I can offer no advise or recommendation on how to best print this model or even how to get it to print properly at all.

If you manage to get this printed properly please link back or otherwise let me know. I'd like to see how it turns out.

description.text:
Ive been trying to resolve a problem with vertical lines that only appears on organic shapes.
A test cube does not show the problem Im trying to fix.
I included some angles to see if it showed up during X&Y moves. Then some round shapes to see if it was only during fast direction changes.
I made this model really small to save material and time, rather than keep printing models with the problem.

Printer:

Tevo Black Widow

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 layer height

Infill:

Only if you print the top

Notes:

The top text leaves a little mess if you dont infill and top layer, but the test still works

comments.text: Hey OwenScenic! They look great! Yeah, the three holes in the sides of the head are for stringing. There should be a hole through the top to bottom of the head also. That hole is for a string that goes all the way through the head, torso, and pelvis to link the body together. It's been a while since I've looked at this to tell you the truth. I'll try to get back to it and give more directions about stringing and a control. I was thinking about an airplane control, here is a great article on marionette controls... http://cat.nyu.edu/~perlin/courses/spring2006/class-0424/04-c-hmm-puppet-d%5B1%5D.pdfhttp://cat.nyu.edu/~perlin/cou...
comments.author: owenscenic

comments.text: Thank you very much for the explanation. Now I understand. I have done only very basic marionette things before, so this is a great learning experience. More info on stringing and control would be a great help for me. I see the 3 hole in the head I assume for stringing, do any of them go down to connect to the torso or is that a separate string? I printed one the same size as the STLs, now I am printing one bigger that will hopefully be easier to string up. I've divided the torso into halves, that made it easier to print on my machine, and maybe easier to string up.

Designed for home decor during the holidays.

Inset a LED tealight into base and cover with bulb of your choice.

Print the bulb section in any color you want. Translucent colors work best.
The base to be printed in opaque colors such as gray. Or painted silver to match a real bulb.

Cheap LED tealights may be too dim. You might be able to substitute the LED for an ultra bright LED.

Print bulb of your choice in clear filament and use RGB LED's for color changing.

Everything modeled in Blender

print_settings.Notes:: I like to make the holes in the standoff feet small, then use a drill to gently drill them out to the needed precise diameter. They can be drilled out to allow a free fit of a mounting bolt (to allow use of nuts, or screwing into other items), or they can be tapped (with a tap, or using self-taping screws) to allow screwing into the foot. (In this case, allow enough material in the foot to accept the threads.)
print_settings.Infill:: Go light, to keep it light (I use 20%)

description.text:
This can be used as a basic spacer/standoff for mounting components (ESC, Flight Controller) to quadcopter frames. It is very configurable, so the size, thickness, foot diameters, etc can all be set to needed/desired values.

This can also be configured adapt different sized boards (in my case, such as the Piko BLX, with a 22.5mm hole spacing) and mounting hole spacings (such as the standard 30mm holes found on many small quads). It can be configured so that the smaller FC can be aligned directly with the larger hole spacing, or mounted at an angle to the larger hole spacing. (Such as is needed on the FlexRC Mini Owl.) The base plate can also be made with a height of zero, resulting in just printing tubular standoffs.

If standoff space is required on both sides of a standoff, simply print 2 standoffs, and place them back-to-back (such as in the picture of the Mini Owl ESC and FC mounting). This is a lot better than trying to print an elevated/supported base plate. (As an example, he perspective picture of the Mini Owl has a 4-footed standoff between the frame and the ESC to keep the ESC off of the frame, another 4-footed standoff upside down above the ESC to clear the ESC components, then an 8-footed, 45-degree-rotated standoff above that, to orient and mount the Piko BLX FC. A bolt passes freely through the frame, the lowest standoff feet, the ESC and the middle standoff feet, then threads into the outer feet of the top-most, 8-footed standoff, which I tapped to accept the bolt. The inner feet of that standoff are also tapped, and the Piko BLX is bolted to it from the top.)

NOTE that the filleting process is slow, so if you open this in Customizer, expect it to take up to a minute to render. Parameter changes will also result in fairly long render times. Reducing the arm_fillet_steps value will help speed things up a bit. If you have OpenSCAD, I'd recommend making changes directly in the tool, as it will render changes faster than the Thingiverse Customizer. (Notwithstanding the slow render time, the Thingiverse Customizer is seriously cool!!)

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

Go light, to keep it light (I use 20%)

Notes:

I like to make the holes in the standoff feet small, then use a drill to gently drill them out to the needed precise diameter. They can be drilled out to allow a free fit of a mounting bolt (to allow use of nuts, or screwing into other items), or they can be tapped (with a tap, or using self-taping screws) to allow screwing into the foot. (In this case, allow enough material in the foot to accept the threads.)
OpenSCAD is a really great tool. This is my 2nd OpenSCAD/CSG design, and I have a hard time imagining going back to a graphical CAD tool, at least for structural type of items.

title: Adjustable Slip-On Threading Tapping Vise Pads (Upright Rods)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
These are slip-on vise pads that are easily adjustable in OpenSCAD. If you want to securely hold screws, bolts, or unthreaded rods and you don't want jaw marks imprinted on your work-piece either, these pads will do the job.

These pads slip around the entire jaw of your vise so they don't easily fall off during use.

To adjust these pads for your bench vise's jaw dimensions, change viseX, viseY, and viseZ parameters (please refer diagrams above). Increase your measurements by 1% to account for ABS shrinkage.

See tips below to prevent warping!

The thickness of the top, bottom, sides, and face are adjustable in millimeters.

Printer:

i3 clone, made in China

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

A raft is not required. I suggest a 10mm brim to minimize warping on the face (you should print the pads face-down).

You need the clamp to press on the "face" of the grain (layers) and not on the edges; otherwise, your pads will crack under pressure.

You are going to absolutely need to keep the whole temperature hot since warping is going to be a problem.

In the OpenSCAD script, I recommend setting "overhang" to zero. This will prevent severe warping. If you minimize viseZ then you will have little or no warping at all (pictured above).

These pads are very good under compression. If you intend to use very high pressure on your vise while using these pads, print at 30% infill, 1.6mm walls, and 1.6mm top/bottom thickness and I will be surprised if you can crack these pads by hand.

In the script, you can increase your vise dimensions by a percentage to account for shrinkage. I recommend adding 1% to your jaw dimensions when printing with ABS. Using 1%, I am able to slip these pads on and off by hand with no slop.

Using the OpenSCAD script, you can change the size of the rod you can hold by changing the value of rRad to the radius of the rod (defaulted to 10mm). You need to manually adjust the position along the viseX dimension using the value rOffset.

For the first face, you should use rod(rRad=,rOffset=). When printing the reverse face, you should use reverseRod(rRad=,rOffset=) to automatically mirror the rod positions. This only matters if "overhang" is nonzero.

Removing Supports

I use a knife and pliers. Only use a file if you have good filtration.

Clean enough! Prevent Warping

Set overhang to zero and you will have very little warping.

Pretty Flat Bad Examples of Warping

Somehow the overhang warps the rest of the piece.

Badly Warped Overhang Difference

I guess if you minimize your viseZ value and make it uniform around the entire piece you will minimize your warping problem.

Left-to-Right: Flat (no overhang), Warped, Flat (no overhang), Warped Threading

I have threaded screws, bolts, and rods without these pads and it takes a lot of pressure; enough to mar the clamped area.

I don't have to squeeze so hard when using these pads.

Testing the pads by adding a few threads (M5-0.8 screw). Proof

I added about 1cm of turns to one of the screws. I posted it here so you know in advance that these pads work fine.

It works fine~

OpenSCAD

I designed this using OpenSCAD. Using the script, you can put your desired rod size in your desired position just by changing a few numbers and pressing "F6."

I hope this comes in handy.

=)

comments.author: JuanS36

comments.text: I did double check things and one side does have some slack in it, interestingly the other side is fairly tight. I'll take the top of the printer off and remeasure everything to see if I can track down the issue. I will say that the main reason these were designed was to fill the gap/void between the top of the screw rod and the plastic frame. Was just trying to keep the top of that rod from wondering around to much.

title: Foot/holder for garden lights - turn them into post lights!

description.text:
Turn your standard Malibu metal garden lights into nice post lights or gate lights with this adapter.

These lights have a standard US 1/2" electrical conduit thread (NP) at the end. The inside of the adapter has a 1/2" NPT thread, while the outside fits in a standard chain link fence post.

Printed with silver ColorFabb PET filament.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Doesn't matter.

Infill:

30 %

comments.text:
Thank you for that, I just measured our posts and they are 60mm outside diameter and 52mm inside making it a tad smaller.
I'm sure I can scale the adapter or even butcher it to suit. I like this it's a lovely idea and would look good on our entry gate.

author: TheLegendarySwimmer

title: TEVO Tarantula Double Y axis rails

description.text:
The Tevo Tarantula double Y axis rails have made a huge improvement to the bed leveling and stability. I don't think the auto bed leveler is now necessary.
Leveling the bed has always been a hit and miss thing, you never knew for sure if it was level or, if it was, did it stay level. Now it does and it is so much easier to do.
Cost: $7.10 + freight and some filament.
I ordered 2 pieces of 2020 aluminium section x 500mm long from Aliexpress.
https://www.aliexpress.com/item/V-Slot-Rail-2020-Black-Anodized-for-OX-CNC-V-Slot-Rail-Aluminium-Profile/32676613548.html?spm=2114.13010608.0.0.y6Os7p

Construction.
Print both pieces from PLA at 0.2 layer height, with 50% fill, no support is needed.
The Rail Spacers has a skirt and the Bed Support has a 5mm brim.
When printing the Bed Support recheck your bed for level and up the bed temperature a bit, being such a large piece I had some lifting in a corner which is OK now.
Print the Rail Spacers from the same colour filament, and off the same roll or you may get a slight variation in size.

Probably the most difficult part for some will be drilling the holes in the acrylic carriage.
The secret is to use negative rake drill bits (see photo). you can do this yourself by either grinding the sharp edge off the drill or rubbing the edge with a grinding stone. If you don't do this, the drill will grab the acrylic and you may even brake it. practice first on a scrap piece.

Drilling the holes.
Screw the Bed Support on to the acrylic carriage using the 4 inner holes, with M5 x 20mm long bolts, washers and nuts. Drill all 4 wheel mounting holes with a 5mm drill first, using the Bed Support as a drilling template, then re drill 2 holes with a 7.5mm drill. Make sure you drill them in the correct place, see first photo.
If you stuff it up you can get a replacement pre-drilled aluminium carriage from Isaac Frankhauser. http://fankhauser.me

The rest is straight forward, mount the Rail Supports to the new 2020 rails and existing 2040 with M4 x 10mm screws, and nuts.
Re assemble and level.
ENJOY.

Tip.
Some of you will have notice I have twisted the belt at the front so that the smooth part of the belt now runs on rollers, the motor end is still the same.

title: Wing tip of RC airplane KRAGA Kodo

description.text:
This is right wing tip of 3D printed RC plane KRAGA Kodo. If you are able to print this part you should be able to print whole plane.

KRAGA Kodo is 1.6m big electric glider (optionally also pure glider) which is printed on 3D printer and reinforced with carbon spars.

More info at https://www.3DprintedRCplanes.com/kodo

Video of assembled plane: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qT2nc_uKL-M

The file is available also here: https://3dprintedrcplanes.com/download_test/kodo/

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Notes:

It has to be printed as shell - 0% infill and no horizontal surfaces (thickness of the shell is one layer).

Nozzle size 0.4 mm.

Result verification

Your result should weight 8 g and you should be able to fit carbon tube with diameter of 4 mm into spar leading holes (bottom side of the part).

Story behind

You can read it here: https://3dprintedrcplanes.com/story_behind/

comments.text: No it's not free and a lot of work went in to the project. If you want someone's design that's free I'm sure you'll find a fidget spinner to fit your pastime needs. For a moment simply try to appreciate the amount of effort that it would take to replicate this design with all the challenges of aerodynamics, structural testing, test assembly, flight testing etc. and you may come to appreciate that the cost is trivial as opposed to the hours one would have to invest. The sunken costs of obtaining the knowledge alone to even embark on such an endeavor is staggering. In terms of relative cost the design is one of the least costly aspects of building one and it is a project which takes time, patients and multiple components to complete. I wish more designs were this elaborate. Without being receptive to people seeking compensation for a significant effort, were going to end up with 3d printing amounting to a collection of fidget spinners.

customized with 3D Slash!

This case for the Raspberry Pi 3 Model B. This model is not a remix, but it was influenced heavily by jayftee's model found at the link below. The main difference is that I made my case slightly larger to cover the USB ports, and gave the case a larger clearance to accommodate the Pi.

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1427797

I gave the Pi a 0.5mm clearance around most features. and made the vertical features separating the Ethernet and USB ports relatively short to allow an easy fit over the Pi.

This case is intended to be paired with four M2 x 0.4mm thread x 20mm long screws which are available at McMaster (Item# 91292A013). You may also find these parts at your local hardware store.

I printed the case using PLA at a 200 um layer height and a 0.5mm extrusion width.

description.text:
I made the first bottle opener to see if it could be done without having a medal insert in it, and also be a slim design. These fit great in pockets. One says "Another ONE!" and was made to be slim/compact. The second, is shaped like a beer can and says "BEER" on it. So far they have worked great, but I have yet to get much use out of them. Enjoy!

Update(12/11/17): So far PETG seems to yield the most durable bottle opener, with PLA working good, and ABS being too soft to hold up.

title: Type A Machines Series 1 G2 Layer Fan Shroud Replacement

description.text:
Testing my own fan shroud and mount design for the G2 hotend on my Type A Machines Series 1 3D printer. I haven't been too satisfied with the cooling abilities of the stock fan and fanshroud, so I'm experimenting with my own design as well as with other fans.

Sorry for the out of focus photos... I'll post better photos and more info as I get more time to work on this one.

12-2-17 Added a new version (G2_Layer_Fan_Shroud_3.stl) which has been re-designed a bit for better air flow, and hopefully more air on the part/less air on hotend. Currently untested. Will update once I have had a chance to test this design.

6-4-17 Added a new version (G2_Layer_Fan_Shroud_2.stl) which features a tighter exhaust for the fan and 4 holes for mounting a fan more effectively. Will follow up with updated photos when time permits.

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

Printed in ABS

comments.text:
This is \the best I've seen for improving the S1 mediocre cooling - very nice!
I'm going to print it for now, but if I could offer a constructive suggestion...
Airflow would be considerably improved if you would "belly out" the bottom curve, so the bottom farthest from the nozzle would be farther from the fan. As it is, when a fan blade is over that 1/8"-deep shallow area, it is generating back-pressure against itself, because the air can't get out from beneath it fast enough. Fans need a plenum downstream from them, to allow the airstream to flow away, instead of bunching up and escaping around the fan blades.
Oh, and maybe maybe round the ends of the exit hole (I prefer the wider one), but aside from that, it's perfect.
comments.author: OldRick

comments.text: This is great feedback OldRick, Thanks! I'll definitely take these suggestions into consideration when I get some time to continue working on this design.
comments.author: OldRick

author: nonaym

title: Soporte ventilador BFB0712H para Prusa i3 Pro B

description.text:
Mi primera creación, es un soporte para colocar un ventilador modelo BFB0712H en el extrusor de Prusa i3 Pro B aprovechando el hueco que hay entre el ventilador del motor, el motor y el soporte de aluminio.

El diseño es un enfriador de capa que cuenta con una pequeña tobera para enfríar el tubo antes del calentador. La boca principal de 41mm de largo por 3mm de alto proporciona un caudal de aire suficiente para enfriar la zona que se está trabajando.
Como se puede observar en las fotos, la boca principal está a unos 3 mm de altura respecto a la punta del nozzle.

El montaje es muy sencillo:
Se desmonta el cabezal completo, separando el motor, disipador y ventilador, luego se desmonta el bloque de aluminio que vá con dos tornillos por debajo del soporte de aluminio, se encaja el diseño quedando el hueco justo donde vá el bloque de aluminio, se coloca el bloque y se atornilla, se monta todo y por ultimo se coloca el ventilador BFB0712H.
Al contar con una pequeña tobera para enfríar el conducto del filamento se puede prescindir del ventilador del disipador.

Prusa i3 Pro B
